item.title: TLS Illustrated
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: If you’ve ever wondered about the individual details of how a TLS exchange works, go take a look at The Illustrated TLS Connection. You can drill down to annotations for each byte. For a detailed look at TLS 1.3 there is The New Illustrated TLS Connection.
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve ever wondered about the individual details of how a TLS exchange works, go take a look at The Illustrated TLS Connection. You can drill down to annotations for each byte.

For a detailed look at TLS 1.3 there is The New Illustrated TLS Connection.

item.title: TLS Security
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Ever get the feeling that it is going to be a bad year for TLS implementations? First the Apple iOS / Mac OS X TLS bug, then a GnuTLS bug. Gives me the feeling that we are just waiting for more of these to be discovered. Ultimately this will be a good thing, but painful […]
item.content:encoded:
Ever get the feeling that it is going to be a bad year for TLS implementations?

First the Apple iOS / Mac OS X TLS bug, then a GnuTLS bug. Gives me the feeling that we are just waiting for more of these to be discovered.

Ultimately this will be a good thing, but painful to get through.

item.title: NGINX TLS Time To First Byte
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Ilya Grigorik on optimizing NGINX TLS time to first byte (TTTFB): let’s now turn to the practical matter of picking and tuning the server to deliver the best results. One would hope that the default “out of the box” experience for most servers would do a good job… unfortunately, that is not the case. Let’s […]
item.content:encoded:
Ilya Grigorik on optimizing NGINX TLS time to first byte (TTTFB):

let’s now turn to the practical matter of picking and tuning the server to deliver the best results. One would hope that the default “out of the box” experience for most servers would do a good job… unfortunately, that is not the case. Let’s take a closer look nginx

In the simplest terms, TLS involves more work. The current realities of securing communications means we don’t have a good way to avoid doing that additional work, indeed we will be doing it more often than we ever have before. The end result is that we need to spend more time thinking about how to optimize the HTTPS experience for all users.

item.title: Tim Bray on IETF
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Tim Bray on IETF 88. Worth following just for the discussion around TLS.
item.content:encoded: Tim Bray on IETF 88. Worth following just for the discussion around TLS.
